id_table_1.caption: Table 1: Category-level object shape and pose estimation methods. TransPoser realizes neural optimization that effectively weighs multiple viewpoints and leverages learned momentum, which enables efficient and accurate joint object shape and pose estimation from sequential observations. We also introduce an efficient neural shape representation, DeepDDF, for this.

id_table_3.caption:
Table 3: 
Ablation study of TransPoser architecture using synthetic data. The baseline [23] corresponds to an architecture without multi-view and momentum. “w/o Dec.” stands for TransPoser without the decoder, i.e., without learned momentum. Metrics for translations (T), rotations (R), and shapes (S) are mean squared error (10−2)superscript102(10^{-2}), Riemannian distance (10−1)superscript101(10^{-1}), and Chamfer distance (10−3)superscript103(10^{-3}), respectively.
For almost all categories, the proposed TransPoser, which learns to weigh multi-view observations and to leverage learnable momentum, achieves highest accuracy.

references:
Tables 5, 4 and 6 quantitatively compares the proposed TransPoser with state-of-the-art methods. TransPoser clearly outperforms other methods including ELLIPSDF [30] that also estimates the pose and shape code. TransPoser required 0.06 sec for each optimization step, and 0.61 sec for a total of 10 iterations with GeForce RTX 2080 Ti. This is approximately 10 times faster than those of ELLIPSDF which required 0.75 sec for its first SGD step.
Note that the exact instances used in the ELLIPSDF are not available [3] and we used the test split of Scan2CAD instead. Examples in Fig. 6 demonstrate that TransPoser can reconstruct plausible 3D shapes even from partial observations. These results show that our neural optimization model successfully learns to leverage the structured bias in category-level shape pose estimation.

id_table_5.caption: Table 5: Accuracy of pose estimation for ScanNet [11]. TransPoser achieves higher accuracy for all categories.

Metrics for translation (T), rotation (R), and shape (S) are the mean squared error (10−2)superscript102(10^{-2}), Riemannian distance (10−1)superscript101(10^{-1}), and Chamfer distance (10−3)superscript103(10^{-3}), respectively. The results show that each component are independently essential to TransPoser.
